docs.abstract: Facebook investors, unhappy with the company's first public financial report, flee the stock in droves; Facebook shares are down 14 percent, to slightly under $23, a new low.

docs.abstract: Mark Zuckerberg gets the billions and the headlines, but an even bigger effect from offerings like Facebook's is the many who score enough wealth to cover their worries, then go take risks. In the next few years, there could be tens of thousands of them.

docs.snippet: An image of police officers dousing seated Occupy Wall Street protesters in the face with pepper spray has quickly become a popular meme online. A cutout of one of the officers, Lieutenant John Pike of the University of California at Davis, has be...
docs.lead_paragraph: Not long after a video of police officers dousing seated Occupy Wall Street protesters in the face with pepper spray surfaced online, it incited anger and disbelief.
docs.abstract: An image of police officers dousing seated Occupy Wall Street protesters in the face with pepper spray has quickly become a popular meme online. A cutout of one of the officers, Lieutenant John Pike of the University of California at Davis, has been edited onto images of tiny kittens, characters from Star Wars and famous pieces of art.

byline.original: By JENNA WORTHAM and NICK BILTON

docs.snippet: It may not be as predictable as Moore's Law, but the amount of data people are sharing on Facebook is growing at blinding speed....
docs.lead_paragraph: One of the most telling moments of Mark Zuckerberg's presentation Thursday morning in San Francisco was a reference to a technology company he said he deeply admired. It wasn't Apple, though his turn on stage seemed to lift several pages from the Steve Jobs playbook. It wasn't Google, from which he has plucked some of his key lieutenants.
docs.abstract: It may not be as predictable as Moore's Law, but the amount of data people are sharing on Facebook is growing at blinding speed.

headline.main: Zuckerberg's Unspoken Law: Sharing and More Sharing
